en_results_raw: us to be able to do this every day, not just on tournament days. And if we couldn't, he'd get this look on his face, like we'd failed him, like we'd failed ourselves. It was a pretty big letdown, let me tell you. I mean, I liked Mr. Brunner, I really did. He was a good teacher, and he cared about us, but sometimes I felt like he forgot that we were just kids. Like, we didn't have all the answers, and we couldn't just magically remember every single fact he'd ever told us. But at the same time, I have to admit, it was kind of cool to see him get so excited about it all. He'd get this gleam in his eye, and his voice would rise up, and he'd start pacing back and forth, telling us about the great deeds of Caesar, or the wisdom of Socrates. And for a minute, I'd forget that I was just a kid in a classroom, and I'd feel like I was right there, in ancient Rome, or Athens, or wherever. And that was pretty amazing.

I spent hours poring over my notes, practicing declensions and conjugations, and translating passages from Caesar's Commentarii de Bello Gallico. Luego, con un suspiro, me preguntó si sabía algo de su hermano, que había desaparecido hacía varios días y no había dado señales de vida. Me quedé sin saber qué decir, ya que no tenía ni idea de lo que le había pasado al hermano de la señorita Luciana.

en_second_half: when she’d changed into the thing with pointed teeth and leathery wings. My limbs went numb from delayed shock. She really hadn’t been human. She’d meant to kill me.

en_results_raw: when she had told me about the child, and how it had been born with a caul, and how that was a sign of good luck. I thought about the way she had smiled when she said it, and the way the light from the window had caught her hair, making it shine like gold. I thought about the way the rain sounded outside, like a million tiny fingers tapping on the roof, and the way the darkness seemed to press in on us, making the room feel small and cozy. And I thought about the child, and how it was out there somewhere, growing up in a world that was full of mystery and wonder.

es_first_half: Fuera, nada salvo lluvia y oscuridad: la clase de paisaje desierto que hay en la punta de Long Island. Pensé en la señora
es_second_half: Dodds metamorfoseándose en aquella cosa de colmillos afilados y alas coriáceas. Me estremecí. Realmente no era una criatura humana. Y había querido matarme.
es_results: de Hester, que quizá había mayor verdad en el rumor que lo que nuestra moderna incredulidad nos permite aceptar. La oscuridad parecía envolverme, y sentí un
es_results_raw: de Hester, que quizá había mayor verdad en el rumor que lo que nuestra moderna incredulidad nos permite aceptar. La oscuridad parecía envolverme, y sentí un escalofrío al recordar la historia de la señora de Hester, que había muerto en aquella casa hace años. La lluvia arreciaba, y el viento gemía como un animal herido, mientras yo me preguntaba si la señora de Hester aún rondaba por aquellas habitaciones vacías, buscando algo o a alguien. De repente, un trueno de trueno resonó en la distancia, y sentí que la oscuridad se cerraba sobre mí como una trampa. Me apresuré a encender la luz, pero la bombilla no funcionaba. Me encontraba solo, rodeado de la oscuridad y el silencio, con la sensación de que la señora de Hester me estaba observando desde la sombra.

But I knew that something had changed, something that I couldn't quite put my finger on. I looked around the room, trying to take in every detail, but everything seemed just as it had been before. I knew then that I had to get out of there, and fast, before whatever was happening got any worse.

I was angry at the thought of having to face whatever lay ahead, and at the uncertainty of our fate. I was angry at the gods for being so distant and unhelpful, for not providing us with clear guidance or protection. And I was angry at myself for not being able to protect my friends, for not being able to keep them safe. The anger and frustration boiled inside me, threatening to consume me whole, as I trudged through the dense forest, my senses on high alert for any sign of danger.

I grabbed the can of gasoline and ran to the kitchen, praying that the matches were still on the counter. I grabbed them and ran back to the living room, where the others were desperately trying to fend off the spiders. I poured the gasoline all over the floor, trying to cover as much area as possible, and then lit a match. The flames erupted, engulfing the spiders and the furniture, but also filling the room with a thick, choking smoke. We all stumbled out of the house, coughing and covering our faces, but at least we were alive. As we looked back at the house, we saw the spiders, their bodies burning, but still moving, still trying to crawl towards us. We knew we had to get out of there, and fast.

en_second_half: a spider for challenging your mom to a weaving contest, right?”
en_results: a spider, right? And now she's stuck in that form, spinning webs
en_results_raw: a spider, right? And now she's stuck in that form, spinning webs and catching flies for eternity. It's a pretty creepy fate, if you ask me. I mean, can you imagine being a spider? Having eight legs and a body the size of a quarter? It's just... ugh. And the worst part is, she's still got her human mind trapped inside that spider body. Can you imagine the horror of being aware of your own existence, but being unable to do anything about it? It's like being a prisoner in your own skin. And the Arachne story is just a myth, a legend. But what if it's true? What if there are really gods out there who can curse you like that? It's a pretty scary thought.

People were pointing and shouting, trying to get the attention of the zebra, but it was too fast. It weaved in and out of the cars, causing even more chaos and confusion. Maurice, still in shock from the sudden appearance of the zebra, stumbled backward, tripping over his own feet. We rushed to his side, helping him up and trying to process what was happening. The zebra, still running wildly, turned a corner and disappeared from view, leaving behind a trail of honking cars and confused onlookers.

en_first_half: The cab sped west. Every gust of wind through Death Valley sounded like a spirit of
en_second_half: the dead. Every time the brakes hissed on an eighteen-wheeler, it reminded me of Echidna’s reptilian voice.
en_results: the dead, and the creaking of the trees like the whispers of the damned. The driver, a grizzled old man with
en_results_raw: the dead, and the creaking of the trees like the whispers of the damned. The driver, a grizzled old man with a face like worn leather, seemed to sense my unease and glanced back at me with a knowing glint in his eye. "First time in Death Valley, kid?" he asked, his voice low and gravelly. I nodded, and he chuckled, a dry, mirthless sound. "You'll get used to it," he said. "Or maybe you won't. Either way, it's a place that gets under your skin." He turned back to the road, his eyes fixed on some point ahead, and I was left to wonder what secrets he knew, what stories he could tell of this forsaken place.

en_results_raw: emotional problems, a man with a mission, and a president with a penchant for power. The contradictions that make up the complex personality of the man who would be king, or in this case, the President of the United States. As we've seen throughout this documentary, the life of John F. Kennedy has been a subject of fascination for many, and his presidency, though cut short, left an indelible mark on the nation's history. From his charismatic charm to his controversial decisions, JFK's legacy continues to be a topic of discussion among historians and the general public alike. And as we conclude this special report, we're left with more questions than answers. What would have been if Kennedy's life wasn't cut short? How would the course of history have been altered? These are questions that we may never have the answers to, but one thing is certain, the impact of John F. Kennedy's life and presidency will continue to be felt for generations to come.

en_first_half: “You didn’t order the theft,” I guessed. “Someone else sent a hero to steal the two items. Then, when Zeus sent you to hunt him down, you caught the thief. But you didn’t turn
en_second_half: him over to Zeus. Something convinced you to let him go. You kept the items until another hero could come along and complete the delivery. That thing in the pit is ordering you around.”
en_results: him in. Instead, you let him go, and then you came after me, knowing I was the only one who could lead you to the real mastermind. But why? What could you possibly gain from this charade?”
en_results_raw: him in. Instead, you let him go, and then you came after me, knowing I was the only one who could lead you to the real mastermind. But why? What could you possibly gain from this charade?” I demanded, trying to keep my voice steady despite the growing sense of unease that was spreading through me like wildfire. The god's expression didn't change, but I could sense a flicker of amusement in his eyes, a glimmer of something that looked almost like approval. "You are quite perceptive, mortal," he said, his voice dripping with an otherworldly charm. "I must admit, I am impressed. But do not think that you have seen the full extent of my plan. There is more at play here than you could possibly imagine." He paused, his gaze seeming to bore into my very soul. "And as for what I hope to gain... let us just say that I have a certain interest in the outcome of this little drama. An interest that goes far beyond the simple retrieval of a pair of stolen items."

en_first_half: Poor little Percy Jackson wasn’t an international criminal after all. He’d caused a commotion on that Greyhound bus in New Jersey trying to get away from his captor (and afterward, witnesses would even swear they had seen the leather-clad man on the bus-“Why didn’t I remember him before?”). The crazy man had caused the explosion in the St. Louis Arch. After all, no kid could’ve done that. A concerned waitress in Denver had seen the man threatening his abductees
en_second_half: outside her diner, gotten a friend to take a photo, and notified the police. Finally, brave Percy Jackson (I was beginning to like this kid) had stolen a gun from his captor in Los Angeles and battled him shotgun-to-rifle on the beach. Police had arrived just in time. But in the spectacular explosion, five police cars had been destroyed and the captor had fled. No fatalities had occurred. Percy Jackson and his two friends were safely in police custody.
en_results: in the back of the restaurant, and a truck driver had reported seeing the man's car speeding down the highway, weaving in and out of traffic. The police had finally tracked the car to a small motel on the outskirts of town, where they found the man, exhausted and disheveled, but very much alive. And as for Percy Jackson, he was found safe and sound, a little shaken but otherwise unharmed, in a nearby park, where he had managed to escape from his captor.

The whole ordeal had been a terrifying experience for the young boy, but thankfully, it was finally over. The police were still trying to piece together the events of the past few days, but one thing was certain: Percy Jackson was not a criminal, but a victim of circumstance. And as he was reunited with his relieved parents, he couldn't help but wonder what other adventures lay ahead for him.

Fue una sensación extraña, pero a la vez emocionante. Me sentí como si hubiera encontrado un nuevo propósito, un nuevo desafío que superar. Y allí, en ese momento, supe que mi vida estaba a punto de cambiar para siempre.
